p.s: Oh no - please not Shakespeare again!I imagine that since all of us have been highschool students, at some point we heard this from one of our classmates when it was announced that we would be reading Shakespeare in class.
As we know, the playwright's works are over 400 years old, so why even bother?
Why do we torture students with the elisabethanElizabethan language that isn't even spoken anymore?
The answer is quite simple: Becausebecause Shakespeare's works still matter because we can still learn from them.
The playwright's themes connected to his works like love, revenge, guilt, fate and hate are undoubtedly a part of our everyday lives.
Let me present an example to you: I assume that ayou have been at least in love once in your life and experienced all that comes with it: pain, when it comes to an end, passion and doubts.
Shakespeare's characters like Romeo and Juliet help to understand these feelings better, illustrate them and provide a philosophical approach we can always come back to.
Another example for the impact his themes have on our society is also hate.
We often do not even rememeber why we hate this particular person.
Does this remind you of someone, doesn't it?
Drawing from Shakespeare, the Montagues and Capulets have been in the same situation.

Especially the end of the play Romeo and Juliet serves as a lecture or rather warning: this violent and useless hate, just for the sake and habit of hating brings nothing but pain and misery to the families.
Apart from the themes in Shakespeare's plays, his language and rhetoric isare quite unique and exceptional.
Did you know that he invented over 1700 words?
Another point to consider that shows us his relevance even more is the mystery that surrounds him.
His works have led to a lot of controversy regarding the long-lasting debate if he had actually written the plays by himself - or as we'd say in nowaday's words - pressed copy-paste.
Shakespeare is obviously still debated about today.
Yet, it is also understandable why some might say that he is outdated.
For instance, the language used by him is extraordinary difficult to understand, especially if English is your foreign language.
In addition to that, it is very often the case that we can't understand his relevance because the plays seem way too boring and complex to follow.
You might even wonder: What do I care about an ancient family feud I barely understand? Don't worry: it is not important to understand each word of the play.
It is rather crucial to understand the lecture behind the story.
To see, that in a world full of hate, love can overcome everything - starting from as simple as an orchard's wall as to even an ancient family feud.
Especially Shakespeare's tragedies ahve had an impact on the theatres around the world and have been of many great examples for the playwrights that came after him.
On the other hand one might also disagree and say that it should be at least modernized to help appeal to audiences of the 21st century.
In conclusion, I maintain the view that Shakespeare is of major importance still in our time.
EventhoughEven though his works are more than 400 years old, they have been and still are serving as an inspiration to other playwrights and their audiences.

Touching on timeless themes like love and hate, the plays as well as their immense literary value regarding language, Shakespeare has undoubtedly impacted your English class and make you either love it or hate it.
It is now up to teachers and actors as well as writers to help preserve his plays and make them appeal to modern audiences.
